content.webTitle: Away days: Southern Stars v West Indies, Bradman Oval, Bowral

fields.headline: Away days: Southern Stars v West Indies, Bradman Oval, Bowral
fields.bodyText: And so to the Southern Highlands for the Southern Stars and a one-day international at Bradman Oval in Bowral. It’s the eighth and final match of a short-form series between Australia and the loose collection of Caribbean islands known as the West Indies, and the locals are well on top. It’s just past midday and Australia are 3 for 127 in 30 overs, with two big guns on deck – all-round superstar Ellyse Perry on 20, and slashing opening bat and captain, Meg Lanning, on 43. And cricket nerdos could watch them all day. Lanning’s batting, particularly, is copybook-attractive. High left elbow, timing, grace, balance, poise, the fluent co-ordination of the natural sporto. And she hits it hard, the ball “thocking” off the middle of the bat with that particular meaty cricket noise of Kookaburra on Gray-Nicholls twin-scoop, or whatever weapons they’re whacking about with today, and whistles across Bradman’s billiard table surface. Bowral? Tidy little town. You can get a Devonshire Tea in Bowral, and buy an antique. A nice bureau, say, or an old chaise lounge. You could visit the Bradman Museum, if you were of a mind, it’s adjacent this delightful oval of the same name. Don Bradman grew up in Bowral, spending untold hours whacking a golf ball against a corrugated iron water tank, developing the preternatural eye and concentration of the run-freak. Doesn’t sound like he had a lot of mates. What? Did someone just sledge the Don? Mayhap they did. The great man was not without barnacles, as none of us are, except for Dennis Lillee. Bradman Oval sports a tight, green surface mowed in concentric circles, with fine big trees dotting the perimeter. There’s a tree-filled escarpment to the east over the ground. Does it have the majesty of Cape Town’s Table Mountain? No, it does not. But it’s not a bad little escarpment, a forested chunk of grey-black rock. And the ground is delightful. Delightful like a friand, say, or a funny gay play. People lounge on deckchairs in that somnolent funk particular to the cricket fan and heroin users on the nod, the one that says I don’t care what’s on the television but I’m here watching, and enjoying it. People knit. People keep score. For the cricket fan, and we are legion, lying back slumped in a deck chair, refreshment in hand, sort of absorbing the soft ebb and flow of a game of cricket … it’s almost meditative, with moments of Top Excitement that can jolt one from one’s seat … woah! How about that? And then you slump back. And repeat. The West Indians? Typically cool and exotic names. Chaquinta Quinton bowls quick and bats number six. Deandra Dottin bats number five and flings the ball from the boundary like it’s shot out a cannon. Shakera Selman is tall and quick, and languid like a long drink in a hammock. But they bowl a lot of pies. And the Aussies feast like fat kids. The crowd? There might be a hundred people. Lot of kids. The girls from the Army, Navy and Air Force are here. Families, locals. Maybe a dozen brightl bibbed security men, standing about, practicing for a day when they might have something to do. Cracker of a day, a sky-blue peach. The most recent game last Sunday it was 35C with a 50-knot southerly, player’s comfort level akin to playing cricket inside Jacquie Lambie’s brain. And so to drinks and Australia are 3/151 in 34 overs. A security man lumbers onto the field, build of a massive pavlova, a man more superfluous than a brassiere on a Brahman bull. Not that superfluous. But superfluous, man. Superfluous. Back into it and … power play! That means the Windies can only put three fielders outside the inner white circle, a sentence lost anyway on non-cricket fans, not sure why I explained it. But what it means is this: The Windies best prepare to chase some leather. And it looks like the Windies know it. Their body language is that of kids in the field on a hot summer’s day. Boom! Lanning smites a cover-drive along the turf for four. Boom! A lofted drive is cracked over mid-off, one bounce, four runs. She clips one off her toes, bottom of the bat, and it’s four more through mid-wicket. When she pulls a short ball to the square leg fence you know this: technically you can’t bat better, man, woman, cricket-playing kangaroo. It’s pure, copybook batsmanship. top stuff, Meg Lanning. Full toss - boom, over mid-wicket. Lanning is 80. Australia 3/190 with 11 overs to go. And the Windies’ fielding dies in the arse. Balls go for four through sweaty palms. It’s game eight of a series they’ve been belted, pillar to post. A wide brings up the Lanning-Perry hundred partnership in 95 balls. I take off for a wander. Giant security pavlova man instructs me not to go on the field. I wasn’t on the field, nor looking like I was going to go on the field. Why would I go on the field? Was it a pre-emptive strike? Does the man have nothing to do? Had he read my notes? And what would he do if I did go on the field? You could run faster than him while pushing a Pajero bogged in a swamp. The silly moo. Over to the scoreboard, a quaint and hand-operated job from days of yore. I take some photos of it, and a fellow scoring. A bloke in an official pink shirt tells me, “You can’t just stand in front of the scoreboard. Happy for you to take some photos after play.” “No worries,” I reply. And stab him in the face with a scimitar! No I don’t. But my, let’s consider old mate’s request. There’s maybe two hundred people here, all of whom can see the scoreboard over my head. I wasn’t likely to set up shop in front of the damned thing. Do I have a sign on my head that says, “Tell this person what to do.”? Wicket! Lanning mistimes a drive and is caught in the deep. Alyssa Healy comes in. And then is gone. Caught. Aussies wobble? Against fellow world-power England, maybe. Against these West Indians they just send in some more top batters to slash and burn. Perry smashes an off-drive, hardest she’ll hit the ball today. Pure, hard, out of the screws. Jess Jonassen smashes a six long down the ground. And does it again! Over midwicket and into the gaggle of service girls who dive on the ball and fight over it, laughing their heads off. Australia, you funny big lug of a country, you beauty. And so Australia finish 5 for 275 and it’s off to the airy outdoor press box to write. The West Indies openers swing early. Bunch of boundaries. Then … wicket! Kycia Knight is caught at first slip. In comes Brittany Cooper. And so the Windies swing and they hit, and they miss and it’s clear these top-order batters can play. But there aren’t enough of them. Perry’s and Megan Schutt’s swingers – a couple of which hoop in like those golden devil-ball things that Harry Potter had to fight in Quidditch – take seven of the nine wickets to fall. Perry will be player of the match and the series. Super cricketer. And as you’re leaving, you see them: a group of tween girls eating icy-poles and waiting for the Aussie girls to come out. When I was a kid girls played cricket by fielding in groups at long on, plaiting their hair and making dandelion necklaces. Today they line up for Ellyse Perry’s autograph. Top stuff. And if you’re looking for a reason Australia should play West Indies in women’s cricket, there you are. Good luck to them.
